qas.question: What role does zinc play in fingers, twists and clusters?

context: Zinc serves a purely <a0_0><b4_0>structural<b4_0/><a0_0/> role in zinc fingers, twists and clusters. Zinc fingers form parts of some <a1_0><b5_0>transcription factors<b5_0/>,<a1_0/> which are proteins that recognize DNA base sequences during the replication and transcription of DNA. Each of the nine or ten Zn2+ ions in a zinc finger helps maintain the finger's structure by coordinately binding to <a2_0><b6_0>four<b6_0/><a2_0/> amino acids in the transcription factor. The transcription factor wraps around <b7_0>the <a3_0>DNA helix<b7_0/><a3_0/> and uses its fingers to accurately bind to the DNA sequence.
